g.text: are the durations of the cold and warm periods, respectively, and
differences between the average temperature at the surface and vegetation during the cold and warm periods (°C).
The mean annual temperature at the depth of seasonal thaw
are the thermal conductivities of the thawed and frozen soil, respectively
are the temperature and temperature amplitude, respectively, at the soil surface.
, there are permafrost regions, and when
, there are seasonal frozen soil or non-frozen soil
The following semi-empirical equation for the depth of seasonal thawing or freezing can be applied
are, respectively, the thermal conductivity (W m
is the latent heat of phase change (J m
). The volumetric heat capacity for soil can be found
Soil type was classified into sand, clay or organic. The International Geosphere–Biosphere Programme
of 4931 soil mapping units and the associated sand and clay content for each soil layer were
used to create a mineral soil texture dataset
. The soil organic matter data were merged from two sources: the
International Soil Reference and Information Centre (ISRIC-WISE)
and the Northern Circumpolar Soil Carbon
. Both datasets report carbon down to 1 m depth. Carbon was partitioned across the top
seven CLM4 layers (~1 m depth) as in Lawrence and Slater
. The soil type and organic data were adapted from
the land surface data of the Community Earth System Model (CESM). The soil column was subdivided into 10
layers, with the maximum depth of soil being 3.8019 m at a resolution of 0.23°
the permafrost areas and permafrost loss calculated in this study indicate permafrost extent at depths less than
3.8 m. Organic matter density was calculated based on the weights of the soil column at 10 soil layers. The layer of
mineral soil and organic matter was considered to be a homogeneous medium with different thermal properties
in the frozen and thawed states. The details of the parameter settings in Kudryavtsev’s method can be found in
1. Zhang, T., Barry, R. G., Knowles, K., Heginbottom, J. A. & Brown, J. Statistics and characteristics of permafrost and ground ice
2. Zhang, Y., Lv, S. H. & Sun, S. F. Climatic effects of frozen soil process in CCM3.
3. Li, X. & Cheng, G. D. A GIS-aided response model of high-altitude permafrost to global change.
Science in China Series D Earth
4. Wang, C. H., Dong, W. J. & Wei, W. Z. Study on Relationship between Freezing-Thawing Processes of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and
the Atmospheric Circulation over East Asia.
5. Wang, C. H., Cheng, G. D., Deng, A. J. & Dong, W. J. Numerical Simulation on Climate effects of freezing-thawing Processes using
Science in Cold and Arid Regions.
. Observations: Surface and AtmosphericClimate Change. In: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis.
Contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [Solomon,
S., Qin, D., Manning, M., Chen, Z., Marquis, M., Averyt, K. B., Tignor, M. & Miller, H. L. (eds)]. (Cambridge University Press,
Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA, 2007).
